entry.title: ACR ‚Äì Business Partner Email Recipient Not Pulled in Statutory Report Distribution
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

Good day!

I‚Äôm currently experiencing an issue in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì Advanced Compliance Reporting (ACR) and I‚Äôd like to ask if anyone here has encountered the same.

Issue Description:

When I run statutory reports (e.g., PH_WHT_BIR2307), the Business Partner‚Äôs maintained email address is not being pulled into the To or CC fields of the email recipient setup.

  • The Business Partner master data has the email address properly maintained.

  • However, the statutory reports are not auto populating the email recipients.

  • As a result, the reports are generated but are sent as print output instead of email.

Expected Behavior:

The system should automatically pull the maintained BP email address for the statutory report distribution.

Actual Behavior:

The To/CC fields remain empty, so no email is sent to the intended recipient.

What I‚Äôve Tried So Far (Based on SAP Support‚Äôs Suggestions):

  1. Checked Email ID and Validity:
    I found that the email ID was not maintained for the supplier (e.g., 1000058), and the address usage validity started on 09/10/2025.

    • Because of this, the email wasn‚Äôt available for the reporting task period 07/01/2025 ‚Äì 09/30/2025.

    • I updated the email and validity as suggested in the help portal:
      Enabling E-Mail Recipients and E-Mail Channel for Business Partner Correspondence | SAP Help Portal.

  2. Output Parameter Determination Adjustments:

    • Step: Channel ‚Üí Deleted the marked entry.

    • Step: Email Recipient ‚Üí

      • Deleted the marked entries.

      • Maintained CC and BCC email addresses as direct value inputs.

    • Followed guidance from Output Parameter Determination | SAP Help Portal.

  3. Updated the Receiver Role:
    SAP Support also advised updating the role from BP to T1 for PH_WHT_BIR2307 in the Output Parameter Determination ‚Üí Receiver step.

    • I applied this change and retested.

Current Result:

Despite these adjustments, the issue persists. The report output still goes to Print instead of being sent via email.

My Question:

Has anyone else experienced this issue in ACR where the Business Partner email isn‚Äôt pulled as the recipient for statutory report distribution?
Are there other configuration steps or prerequisites that I might be missing to make the system automatically pull the BP emails?

I‚Äôd really appreciate any insights or recommendations you could share.

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: API "Billing Document - Read, Cancel, GetPDF" : how to consume in ABAP Cloud ?
entry.content:
The reason for the Internal Error is :

  • Class : CL_HTTP_DESTINATION_PROVIDER
  • Method : create_by_comm_arrangement

There is a local variable declared lv_destination of type rfcdest which is type char32 which is filled in line 260 from the variable logical_port which is type char 60.

LOGICAL_PORT = ZCA_100_7ILD5FN2FYP6BEETPYCZFBT4AY   --> 34 characters ! Will be truncated to 32 characters !

--> lv_Destination : will get a truncated value

entry.title: Re: Clarification on how ‚ÄúLinked Object‚Äù is populated for...
entry.content:
Hi @ludgero_vasconcelos 

What OCN Does and Doesn‚Äôt Send
The OCN completion event payload contains Item ID, Completed Date, Result, duration and optional score.
It does not include Content Object metadata (like Content Object ID, Description, Launch Method, Filename).
This is true for both Skillsoft, LinkedIn Learning, Coursera and other OCN connectors ‚Äî since the completion is posted at the item level.

Implication for OCN
With OCN, completions come via the OCN event feed:
If the learner launched the OCN resource through LMS at least once (meaning the item‚Äôs content object was activated in the LMS content structure), the LMS can attach that object info.


If completion arrives from OCN without any LMS-based launch history, LMS will:
Record the completion at item level
Leave ‚ÄúView Object Details‚Äù empty because there is no content object session binding.


That‚Äôs why for OCN-generated completions you may see item completion without content object details in reports.

Regards 

Harisree CL

entry.title: Re: Reporting on LMS data in Story Reporting
entry.content:
Hi @tduncan 

1. LMS Story Reporting Data Model
When you enable Learning Data in People Analytics, SAP exposes specific logical tables. The key ones for your case:

Table Name (Story Reporting) What it Represents
Item - Course/Curriculum/Component master data. Each record is a learning item.
Item Revision - Versions of learning items. Useful when courses have multiple revisions.
Class - Scheduled offerings for ILT items.
Content Object - SCORM/AICC/TinCan objects inside Items.
Registration - User registrations into items/classes.
Learning History - Completion and transcript records.
User - Learner master data.
Instructor - Instructor profiles.

2. Why You See Duplicate Course Titles

You likely have joins between Learning History and Item without restricting by Item ID or without using the Item Revision dimension, so:
Different items can have the same title (e.g., ‚ÄúSafety Training‚Äù) but different Item IDs in LMS.
Item Title field comes from the Item table ‚Üí Title column
But titles are not guaranteed unique in LMS.
Best practice: Always pull Item ID + Title together if you need to distinguish courses.
Example for Learning History join:
Learning History ‚Üí Item ID
Join Item ‚Üí Item ID ‚Üê This gives you the correct title for the completed item.

Regards 

Harisree CL

entry.title: Int4 Suite ‚Äî your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
entry.content:
Intro

Want to build reliable Joule skills and agents without breaking anything (or anyone‚Äôs nerves)? Treat Int4 Suite as your Joule testbed and skills builder: a place where you discover the real shape of a skill from historical traffic, scaffold its definition, rehearse end-to-end flows in a safe sandbox, and wire everything into MCP or CI/CD so quality checks can happen automatically.

This post shows a pragmatic playbook for S/4HANA + SAP BTP Integration Suite teams to use Int4 beyond SAP API testing and simulation as a preparation and enablement layer for SAP Business AI.

Why does Int4 belong in your Joule toolchain? 

  • Reality-first inputs. Int4 stores and mines historical electronic messages (IDoc/OData/REST) and master data, gold for grounding AI skills in how your business actually runs.
  • Process-aware, agentic orchestration. It doesn‚Äôt just fire single APIs; it understands and can prepare the business context, chaining SO‚ÜíDelivery‚ÜíInvoice and fixing missing prerequisites on the fly. SAP Community
  • Safe simulation. Int4 Suite virtualizes third-party/partner systems so you can shadow-run agents end-to-end without touching production endpoints.
  • Modern hooks. SAP‚Äôs Joule Studio gives your agents standard tool interfaces; Int4‚Äôs actions and datasets slot right in.

1) Discover the real skill you need (from history)

Problem: Spec sheets rarely match production reality. Which fields are really required? What defaults do users rely on? Which edge cases appear in the wild?

How:

  • Mine historical interface messages across S/4HANA and Integration Suite: pull IDocs, OData/REST payloads for Sales Orders, Deliveries, Invoices, etc. Use them as canonical examples and edge cases for your skill‚Äôs inputs/outputs and constraints.

Figure - Int4 Suite - Robotic Crawler to fetch millions of historical API postings 

  • Reconstruct end-to-end flows (e.g., SO‚ÜíDelivery‚ÜíInvoice) from those messages so your skill spec mirrors the actual business process, not just API docs. This is the core of process-aware agentic testing in Int4. SAP Community

Figure - Int4 Suite - Fix issues with missing stock for a business process posting (outbound delivery part of the Order to Cash process)

Why it matters: You stop guessing which fields matter and start from observed truth, exactly the inputs your Joule skill must handle.

2) Auto-scaffold skill definitions for Joule Studio

Problem: Turning messy real-world payloads into a clean skill I/O schema (and examples) is tedious and easy to get wrong.

How:

  • From mined payloads, extract: required vs. optional fields, typical defaults, allowed value ranges.
  • Turn that into your Joule skill definition (inputs/outputs plus example payloads) in Joule Studio.

Figure - Int4 Suite dimensions created automatically from historical API calls can be used to create Joule skills 

  • Use Int4 Robotic Crawler outputs, hundreds of realistic variants, to seed positive, boundary, and negative examples that harden your prompts/spec.

Why it matters: You get a model-ready spec, grounded in real data, with examples covering the weird cases you‚Äôd otherwise miss.

3) Safe sandboxes for agent rehearsal (‚Äúshadow mode‚Äù)

Problem: Early skills need practice with all their integration touch-points but production endpoints are risky and partners are not always available.

How:

  • Use Int4 Suite to virtualize 3rd-party/partner APIs and even replay historical responses; point your early Joule skill/agent to this sandbox. Run full E2E flows, including error/failure drills, without touching live systems.
  • Pair with SAP S/4 or iFlow stubs so multi-step scenarios can execute safely (e.g., simulate 3PL delivery confirmations, EDI partner messages).

Why it matters: You ‚Äúflight-test‚Äù the skill‚Äôs decisions and error handling in realistic conditions, safely.

4) Wire Int4 Suite into your MCP + CI/CD toolchain

Problem: Skills evolve. APIs and iFlows change. You need automatic quality gates‚Äîevery time.

How:

  • Wrap Int4 actions as MCP tools so your dev copilot or even Joule Studio automations, can call them during build/validation.
  • Let SAP Cloud ALM/DevOps trigger Int4 suites when Joule skills or iFlows change; Int4 already supports automated test-case harvesting and orchestration around Integration Suite.

Why it matters: Every transport becomes self-verifying. Skills can‚Äôt drift out of compliance without getting caught.

How does this complement SAP‚Äôs Business AI?

  • Joule Studio remains where you author skills/agents. Int4 feeds it: schemas, examples, and safe endpoints.
  • MCP servers are how agents call tools; Int4 becomes a tool provider (testing, data seeding, etc.). 
  • Integration Suite + Cloud ALM keep operations clean; Int4 strengthens them with evidence-driven regression around API and iFlow changes.

Figure - Int4 Suite - validate changed APIs or iflows

Where to learn more

  • Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite - why ‚Äúagentic‚Äù tests matter and how Int4 auto-prepares missing context. SAP Community
  • Agentic Testing & Simulation with Int4 Suite‚Äôs SAP Business Knowledge Graph - democratizing simulation & semantic search over test cases. SAP Community
  • Cloud ALM with Integration Suite - monitoring and change-driven automation hooks. SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Learning Notification not received in SF MS Teams chat
entry.content:
Hi @joy2dworld 

1. Why LMS items behave differently

SAP SuccessFactors LMS:
Generates To‚ÄëDos internally for Learning Assignments and Approvals.

These To‚ÄëDos are visible in the SF "To‚ÄëDo List" widget because the Platform UI queries LMS via an internal learning microservice.
However, Teams notifications are driven by the Work Tech Integration To‚ÄëDo APIs and Intelligent Services events.

By default:

LMS learning assignments are not included in the Work Tech-supported To‚ÄëDo API feed unless you enable Learning in Unified To‚ÄëDo Feed.
Many LMS-generated tasks also don‚Äôt appear in the Home Page Tiles unless "New Home Page" is enabled and Learning is configured to push those tasks via the To‚ÄëDo framework.

2. Extra Setup Needed

A. Enable LMS in the Unified To‚ÄëDo Framework
In Admin Center ‚Üí Manage To‚ÄëDo Alerts and Notifications:
Check for Learning task types and ensure they are enabled for cards.
For some customers, SAP must enable the Learning To‚ÄëDos in To‚ÄëDo Service via a backend toggle ‚Äî you may need to raise a Support ticket.
SAP KB: 3004742 ‚Äî Learning To‚ÄëDos not appearing in People Profile or Work Tech cards.

B. Intelligent Services Event Subscription
The Work Tech integration listens for Intelligent Services events (ISE) such as:
Learning Item Assigned
Learning Item Pending Approval
Learning Completion Recorded
Check in Admin Center ‚Üí Intelligent Services Center:
Locate events under ‚ÄúSAP Learning‚Äù category.
Subscribe them to the Microsoft Teams channel that Work Tech uses.
For Approvals, check ‚ÄúLearning Request Requires Approval‚Äù event.
Note: Not all Learning events are enabled for Work Tech out of the box ‚Äî some require that you have Learning Approval Service active via OData.

C. LMS OData & To‚ÄëDo API Exposure
Learning cards in Teams and SF Home Page cards pull from To‚ÄëDo API (/odata/v4/Todo):
In Provisioning ‚Üí Enable SAP SuccessFactors Learning for To‚ÄëDo Integration.
This ensures Learning To‚ÄëDo objects (e.g., LearningAssignment, LearningApproval) are exposed to the unified card generator.
For integrated tenants, this is managed via BizX‚ÄìLMS integration settings in Provisioning:

Enable new Learning Home Page Tiles
Enable Learning To-Do Integration
Enable Learning Filter in To-Do service

These three toggles must be ON.

D. Home Page Tile/Card behaviour
Old homepage: Learning assignments appear only in To‚ÄëDo list, not as tiles.
New home page framework (2021 onwards): Requires you to activate Learning Tiles in Configure Home Page and map them to the unified To‚ÄëDo service.
Path: Admin Center ‚Üí Configure Home Page ‚Üí Add Card ‚Üí Select ‚ÄúLearning ‚Äî Required Learning‚Äù or ‚ÄúLearning ‚Äî Approvals‚Äù.

3. Key Points
Work Tech cards for Teams rely on Unified To‚ÄëDo feed + Intelligent Services events.
LMS assignments & approvals will not show unless Learning To‚ÄëDo integration is configured and backend toggles enabled.
You may need SAP Support to confirm your tenant has Learning tasks mapped to the To‚ÄëDo framework.
The Employee To‚ÄëDo list is richer and can display LMS items even if they‚Äôre not available as Teams cards ‚Äî because it directly queries LMS via internal API.

4. Recommended Action Plan
Check To‚ÄëDo configuration: Admin Center ‚Üí Manage To‚ÄëDo Alerts and Notifications ‚Üí Verify Learning tasks are enabled.
Verify Intelligent Services events: Admin Center ‚Üí Intelligent Services Center ‚Üí Search "Learning".
Check Provisioning toggles (requires partner/SAP access):
Enable Learning in Unified To‚ÄëDo feed.
Enable new Learning Home Page Tiles.
Add Learning cards to SF Home Page via Configure Home Page.
If LMS tasks still don‚Äôt appear in Teams, raise SAP Support Ticket requesting enablement of Learning To‚ÄëDo API entities for Work Tech integration.

Regards 

Harisree CL

entry.title: The strength of a community can be seen in events like SAP Inside Track Porto 2025
entry.content:
This past weekend I had the privilege of once again taking part in SAP Inside Track Porto 2025, held at the inspiring Hotel Forte de Gaia. It was a very special event, not only because of the unique atmosphere and the energy of the SAP community, but also because I had the honor of contributing in two ways: as an organizer and as a speaker.

The SAP community in Portugal keeps surprising me with the quality of knowledge shared and the spirit of collaboration that grows stronger each year. This year‚Äôs agenda struck a great balance between highly technical topics ‚Äî such as innovation with CAP and AI Agents ‚Äî and hands-on experiences in S/4HANA projects and SAP Cloud ERP. Each session was an opportunity to learn something new and exchange insights with colleagues and friends who, like me, believe that the real strength of the community lies in sharing real-world experiences.

In my session, I spoke about bank connectivity in SAP, presenting a project we delivered in partnership with MAKEVALUE and SIBS LABS. I demonstrated how APIs and direct integrations can simplify critical financial processes: from payments and collections to bank statements, Open Finance, and instant payments. It was very rewarding to share the results and see the audience‚Äôs interest in exploring these scenarios, which are increasingly becoming part of companies‚Äô daily operations.

The event closed on a memorable note with live music, reminding us that technology and culture can ‚Äî and should ‚Äî walk hand in hand.

I left this SIT Porto 2025 with a strong sense of accomplishment, but also with renewed inspiration to keep investing in this community that grows year after year. A special thank you to all the speakers, participants, and colleagues who made this gathering possible.

And, as tradition, the positive balance of the event will be donated to a social support institution, reinforcing the idea that the SAP community is not only about technology but also about making a positive impact on society.

See you at the next SIT!

entry.title: Re: Display of Opening Movement from balance carryforward...
entry.content:
Hello @BlasRosello4 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, balance carryforward records open with opening balances in Period 000 of ACDOCA without generating an FI document. Since AR_JOURNAL_LEDGER is document-based, these Period-0 balances won‚Äôt show up in the Libro Diario. It‚Äôs intentional, S4HANA Public Cloud  

Here are some ways customers typically manage this in practice:

Try posting a legal opening journal on Day 1 (Period 001) to create a real FI document that flows into AR_JOURNAL_LEDGER. Use the Post Opening Balances / Schedule Post Closing and Opening Balances features, as auditors often find this helpful.  SAP Help Portal-Post Opening Balances

If your auditor agrees, consider adding an opening line through a DRC manual adjustment. This way, the statutory extract will show the opening movement, and the Period-0 carryforward remains unchanged. To do this, simply configure and run the Journal Ledger ‚Äì Argentina report in DRC. SAP Help Portal-Setting Up the Journal Ledger

There is no default switch to set AR_JOURNAL_LEDGER to read Period-0 carryforward automatically. To ensure full compliance with Libro Diario, it's best to post an opening journal entry as recommended. If that's not possible, a DRC manual adjustment with an auditor‚Äôs sign-off can be used as an alternative.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: reset password for S User
entry.content:
Hi Marija,

To help the user set their initial password, please follow the steps outlined below using Forgot Password link detailed in KBA 1808560:

1. Go to Forgot My Password

2. Enter S-user ID S00xxxxxxxx 

3. Click Continue

4.An email will be sent from SAP ID Service (ias@notifications.sap.com) to the email address registered for the user.

5. Locate the email and use the password reset link provided.

  • Password reset link is valid for 2 hours from the time it was generated from the system, and can only be used once. If the password reset link expires before you reset the password, repeat the steps above.
  • If no e-mail is received from ias@notifications.sap.com, make sure the S-user's e-mail address is valid and that it isn't being routed to the user's spam/junk e-mail folder. If no e-mail is found, send an e-mail to SAP ID Service directly at: sso@sap.com

Please feel free to contact us if you have any questions. 

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Enterprise Service Management in Action: AI-Driven Service Experiences at SAP Connect 2025
entry.content:
Enterprise Service Management at SAP Connect 2025

SAP Connect is about more than bringing people together ‚Äî it‚Äôs about uniting ideas, innovation, and technology to shape the future of work. This year, SAP SuccessFactors Enterprise Service Management takes the spotlight, showcasing how organizations can deliver seamless, AI-driven service experiences across HR and beyond.

From inspiring keynotes to roadmap deep dives, demos, and customer stories, you will see how SAP is helping businesses:

  • Empower employees with intuitive, guided self-service
  • Boost HR efficiency through intelligent automation
  • Increase agility and scalability with data-driven insights
  • Extend service delivery into finance, procurement, and more
  • Integrate AI into everyday interactions to make services smarter and faster

Whether you are exploring the latest innovations, seeking practical strategies, or learning from customer journeys, there‚Äôs an Enterprise Service Management session designed for you.

Enterprise Service Management Highlights at SAP Connect

HCM Keynote: Unprecedented Possibilities ‚Äî Connecting Your People and Your Business

October 7 | 8:30 ‚Äì 9:30 AM
Watch Dan Beck demo ESM in action and highlight innovations that redefine HR service delivery with AI, simplicity, and efficiency.

Demo Pod: Core HR & HR Service Delivery | All Conference Days

Experience ESM capabilities firsthand. Presales experts will guide you through live examples and answer your questions.

Roadmap Session: The Future of HR Service Delivery

October 7 | 12:45 ‚Äì 1:30 PM
Explore what‚Äôs next for ESM, from AI automation to collaboration integrations and new service delivery models.

Customer Story & Roundtables: Corning

  • Customer Story | October 7 | 2:30 PM
    Hear how Corning is transforming HR service delivery with ESM ‚Äî their challenges, strategies, and results.

  • Roundtable Discussions

    • October 7 | 12:00 ‚Äì 12:55 | CCCR2756

    • October 8 | 14:00 ‚Äì 14:55 | CCCR2748

Engage directly with Corning‚Äôs HR leaders for hands-on insights into their ESM journey.

Strategy Session: Early Insights & Customer Outcomes

October 8 | 1:00 PM
See how early adopters are reaping the benefits of automating HR service delivery.

Demo Session: AI in ESM

October 8 | 3:00 PM
Discover how AI powers ESM ‚Äî from auto case categorization and routing to real-time translation and automated summaries.

Beyond HR: Expanding Service Experiences

While ESM is transforming HR service delivery, SAP Connect also showcases how service innovation extends across the business:

  • Solution Demo: Centralize, standardize, and scale with SAP Enterprise Service Management | October 7 | 2:30 PM

  • Workshop: Navigating the Transition to Service Cloud Version 2 | October 8 | 1:00 PM

Why Attend

By joining these sessions, you will:

  • Experience AI-powered service delivery in action

  • Get an inside look at the ESM roadmap and innovations

  • Learn from customer stories and roundtables that bring the technology to life

  • See how SAP‚Äôs service innovations extend beyond HR to customers and partners

These are just a few highlights of many. Check out the full event catalog and venue details here. To learn more about how Enterprise Service Management helps customers today, visit SAP.com.

See you in Las Vegas!

entry.title: Tax Allowance in Depreciation for Malaysia
entry.content:
Hi SAP Expert,

When it comes to depreciation run, there is no option to select the depreciation for tax (depreciation area: 15) in S4Hana public cloud.

For Malaysia, there is a legislation requirement to capture tax allowance for puchase of asset.

20% Initial Allowance (IA) of acquisition value for first year and then 10% Annual Allowance (AA) annually on remaining value

Is it possible to have depreciation key to reflect the 20% Initial Allowance of asset acquisition for the first year and 10% Annual Allowance annually on remaining value for subsequent years?

entry.title: Re: Identity Provisioning Service(IPS)-Assigning Custom Attributes to IAS Users with Transformation
entry.content:
Hi @Yogananda , 

Thanks for sharing your insights.

I too am considering the option of using custom attributes. However, after reading Mohammed's blog on SAP Ariba User Provisioning Using SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS), would it be a better approach to create and use a custom schema in IPS with the required attributes for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) Teams mapping?

My Organisation has 2 use cases that I am investigating to determine if SAP Cloud Identity Services is a viable replacement solution as a one stop shop to manage all users from a single central solution for both on-premise and cloud applications? 

  1. As a replacement for AS ABAP Central User Administration (CUA) on S/4 HANA with CIS IPS. However I am finding that there are many gaps in the model of how CUA/SU01 and Employee BP (Business User) are used and what CIS IPS user management provides. Here I am exploring to see if I can use Custom Attributes to fulfill the gaps. (Given that 5 of the custom attributes are theoretically reserved for SAC, this only leaves 5 remaining.) I am now thinking custom schema to fill the gaps? 
  2. Managing users on SAC where we already use a Teams mapping approach. (Again should we use custom attributes or create a custom schema for SAC users?)  

I'd like to hear your view on the use case of using 'Custom Attributes' as compared to implementing and using a custom schema approach?

Thanks

Regards

Steve.

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: error KO115 when closing production order
entry.content:
We have seen this message when Production Order deletion.

We tried to set a deletion flag in CO02 and this error message occurred.

We try to produce a material with BOM, and component material has been issued.

Thus, cost price for component material was not balanced to 0, and error message was displaying.

What we did is that we have done MIGO to offset movement type so that costing would be balanced.

After doing MIGO, we were able to set a deletion flag in CO02.

entry.title: Re: proposal of more than 99 conditions supplement not po...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, SAP hard-limits the number of condition supplements that can be proposed to 99. Even if you see fewer in the contract, the system may be generating more in the background. Sometimes multiple access sequences, condition records, or overlapping pricing procedures generate supplements you don‚Äôt expect. If your pricing procedure or condition type configuration allows multiple supplements, the system may be stacking them up. The contract creation process may trigger condition supplements from multiple sources (e.g., master data, condition tables, or user exits).

To your question "How to replicate in a lower environment", perform the below steps:


  • Copy the same pricing procedure from production into your test system.
  • Create a contract with the same material/vendor/customer combination that triggers the error.
  • Trace pricing:
    • Use Transaction: VKP or Pricing Analysis in the contract.
    • Check which condition types are pulling in supplements.
    • Count how many are being proposed (including hidden/duplicate ones).
  • If you want to stress-test, deliberately create condition records with many supplements (close to 99) and simulate contract creation.

entry.title: Join SAPUI5 Sessions at SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Dear UI5 enthusiasts,

SAP TechEd 2025 is where UI5 developers meet to enhance their knowledge and get hands-on experience. This is the type of content you like to see: Understand the strategy, see highlights and try out latest capabilities around SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements.

SAP TechEd in 2025 kicks off on the 4th of November 2025, and preparations are in full swing in SAP. As you probably know, SAP TechEd is the leading tech conference for all developers, IT professionals, business experts, eager to gain in-depth knowledge of SAP‚Äôs technologies. It also offers an excellent opportunity to network and connect with peers and SAP experts.

 

SAP TechEd 2025: Registration is live ‚Äì check out our brand new hybrid experience!

Access the full SAP TechEd 2025 session catalogs:  SAP TechEd Berlin and SAP TechEd Virtual and see my shortlist here:

Keynote

KEY100 | Beyond the hype: How SAP is supercharging developers for what's next
Some experts argue there‚Äôs a developer shortage. Others will say developers are no longer needed due to AI. Let‚Äôs get real: developers, architects, and technologists are here to stay, and their roles are more important than ever.

Strategy Talks

ST117 | SAP‚Äôs user experience strategy with SAP Build
An intuitive user experience is essential for every business user. Examine SAP‚Äôs strategy for evolving SAP Build Work Zone to empower a streamlined digital workplace, and for building efficient SAP Fiori apps with SAPUI5. Hear how SAP is advancing with Joule, our AI copilot, now embedded across SAP Build solutions.

ST116 | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools - also available virtually as ST116v
Explore the most recent innovations in SAP Build solutions that help developers to create extensions, applications, and automations. Learn how enhancements in the development environment, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, and Joule copilot empower customers and partners to build extensions efficiently at scale.

Deep Dives

AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build - also available virtually as AD106v
Discover what‚Äôs new in SAPUI5 development with SAP Build solutions. Learn to build modern SAP Fiori apps across ABAP and the cloud using new developer tools, Joule technology integration, and proven SAPUI5 capabilities. Get insights into SAP‚Äôs UI strategy with SAP Web Components and see how you can benefit. Elevate your UI with SAPUI5 in SAP Build.

AD203 | Fact-checking UI extensibility on cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you
SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps in a clean core approach. Key users use drag-and-drop tools while developers add custom code with visual editors and the Joule copilot. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and ABAP RESTful application programming model help extend data models and add custom logic in SAP Build solutions.

AD100 | Joule for developers: How AI can boost your development in SAP Build
The Joule for developers add-on combines all the AI capabilities in SAP Build solutions. Learn about AI-driven development and how developer productivity can be increased. Developers can use our productivity tools to make their lives easier when engaging in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development.

CA105 | Intelligent app development at scale with AI and SAP Fiori elements

With exciting updates to building blocks, a streamlined entry page, and powerful generative AI in SAP Fiori tools, developers can build applications faster than ever. Get a first look at how we integrate MCP to orchestrate AI capabilities across SAP Fiori tools and SAP Fiori elements for faster app development.

AD201 | Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it for ABAP developers

Understand the importance of our strategic approach of integrating ABAP Cloud into SAP Build solutions. Find out how you can benefit from this for SAP Fiori app development and how the graphical modeler helps you to create ABAP core data services models conveniently. Finally, get insight into our future direction.

Roadmap Sessions

AD818 | Explore the road map for user experience with SAP Build
SAP Build solutions feature many new and upcoming user experience capabilities. Find out how SAP Build Work Zone delivers a connected, intuitive digital workplace, including the SAP Mobile Start app. Understand SAP's road map for building SAP Fiori apps with SAPUI5. See how the Joule copilot supports user and developer productivity.

AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions - also available virtually as AD820v
Check out upcoming enhancements to SAP Build solutions involving SAP‚Äôs professional developer tools, the Joule copilot, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAPUI5, and SAP Fiori apps. These updates boost developer productivity, support clean core, and improve extensibility for line-of-business (LoB) apps, advancing enterprise app development.

Hands-on Workshops

AD166 | Taking UI to the next level: Develop SAPUI5 with SAP Build
Use SAP Build solutions to develop a modern app with SAPUI5. Explore latest best practices, including the UI5 linter and TypeScript to build a future-proof app. Get to know SAP Web Components and leverage them in your SAPUI5 app. Gain hands-on experience, ask questions, and see how Joule technology supports you with AI-based SAPUI5 magic.

AD260 | UI extensibility on top of cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you
SAPUI5 flexibility lets you extend SAP Fiori apps with a clean core approach. Key users and developers can add custom code with visual editors and Joule technology. See how SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and the ABAP RESTful application programming model support extending data models and adding custom logic in the SAP Build solution.

AD160 | Get hands-on with Joule: Boost your SAP Build development with AI
The Joule for developers add-on brings AI capabilities directly into SAP Build solutions to support your development process. Get hands-on experience using AI-driven tools to boost your productivity in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model and UI development, with features designed to simplify your workflow and help you build faster and smarter.

CA261 | Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5

Learn how to create new SAP applications with great UX and AI using the reusable components, patterns, and floor plans in SAP Design System. Design with the SAP Fiori for Web UI kit from Figma, harness AI and the MCP protocol for automated app generation and real-time adaptation of SAP Fiori elements, and extend freestyle in SAPUI5.

AD163 | Fusion development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build

Practice fusion development of ABAP Cloud in SAP Build solutions by creating an ABAP Cloud project from the lobby for SAP Build to develop an ABAP RESTful application programming model business object, including an SAP Fiori app on top.

It sounds awesome, right? I KNOW!
See you there...

entry.title: Re: Manage Processing Rules - For Bank Statements
entry.content:
Hi @CGLIT ,

Thank you for your questions. I shall try and answer them. 

As to your 1. question:
If you create a processing rule with the AP/AR Posting action type, then yes: You need to specify in the rule's action (in the Post to AP/AR Account section) who exactly the supplier or customer is by selecting the right account. 
On the other hand, if you select G/L Posting as the action type though, then you can leave the rule's actions empty and the system is going to derive the right G/L account itself in most cases.

As to your 2. question:
If you select Clear in Sequence as the rule's action type, then you can select any available processing instructions. It doesn't necesarily have to be the 010 processing instruction. You can also select any and multiple of the processing instructions described in this help content here: Overview on All Predelivered Processing Instructions
And no, selecting the Clear in Sequence action type does not mean that you need to process the bank statement items manually. You can automate your processing rules so they run in the background and automatically process your bank statement items. For more detailed information see also: 

  • How to Create Processing Rules
  • How to Automate Processing Rules

I hope that info helps. You can also find more information on the SAP Help Portal under Bank Statement Processing.

Best regards,
Anita

entry.title: Re: Please suggest the BAdI name for controlling sales pr...
entry.content: In standard SAP SD pricing, if you enter the same manual condition type (like your ZPR1) multiple times for the same line item, the system will keep all the entries in the pricing screen, but only the last one remains active in the calculation. The earlier ones are flagged as inactive. Still if you want to restrict this, you can try with BAdI to enforce the restriction. The relevant enhancement spot is SD_COND_SAVE_A (Pricing Conditions).

entry.title: Re: Tax Allowance in Depreciation for Malaysia
entry.content:
Hello @S0027169027 ,

Thanks for the question. Below is a list of what is available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and the requirements of Malaysia‚Äôs regulations.

In the Public Cloud, depreciation keys come pre-set. You won‚Äôt be able to create or freely adjust a key to perfectly match 20% Initial Allowance in the first year and then 10% Annual Allowance afterwards. SAP Help Portal-Depreciation Key

Depreciation area 15 ‚Äì Local Tax is used to hold tax values, but it depends on the specific keys and methods provided. There does not seem to be publicly available evidence of a Malaysia key matching the 20/10 pattern out of the box. SAP Help Portal-Depreciation Areas

Malaysia‚Äôs capital allowance regime generally allows for an initial 20% deduction in the first year, followed by an additional 10‚Äì20% often around 10% for specific classes. Remember, this is related to taxes, not the depreciation shown in books. PwC Tax Summaries

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Principal Propagation Setup for HTTPS and RFC (SNC) Protocol from SAP BTP to S/4HANA
entry.content:
Principal Propagation Setup for HTTPS and RFC (SNC) Protocol from SAP BTP to S/4HANA

In this blog, we'll walk through how to configure Principal Propagation from SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) to an on-premises S/4HANA system, using SAP Cloud Connector and SAP Web Dispatcher. We are configuring principal propagation to an S/4HANA system for HTTPS communication and RFC communication using SNC.

References

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/configuring-principal-propagation

About

Principal propagation is the secure process of forwarding a cloud user's identity from a cloud environment to an on-premise system, enabling single sign-on (SSO) and ensuring the user's personal authorizations apply. It relies on a trusted relationship between the cloud and on-premises systems, using mechanisms like JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) or certificates to pass the user's context unchanged, allowing the backend system to recognize the individual user and their permissions.

Scenario: Cloud to On-Premises

  1. A user logs in to the cloud application. Its identity is established by an identity provider (this can be the default IdP for the subaccount or another trusted IdP).
  2. The cloud application then uses a user exchange token (or a designated secondary header) to propagate the user to the Connectivity service. Optionally, the application may use the Destination service to externalize the connection configuration that points to the target on-premise system.
  3. The Connectivity service forwards the JWT (that represents the user) to the Cloud Connector.
  4. The Cloud Connector receives the JWT, verifies it, extracts the attributes, and uses its STS (security token service) component to issue a new token (for example, an X.509 certificate) with the same or similar attributes to assert the identity to the backend (BE1-BEm). The Cloud Connector and the cloud application share the same trust settings.
  5. The Cloud Connector sends the new token (for example, an X.509 certificate) to the backend system.

Pre-requisite

  • Ensure that the SAP Cloud Connector (SCC) is installed and its initial setup has been completed. Refer to the SAP Help documentation.
  • The Cloud Connector should be connected to your SAP BTP subaccount by adding the subaccount details within the SCC. Refer to the SAP Help documentation
  • Additionally, trust must be established between your subaccount and the SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant. This trust setup allows integration with any corporate identity provider and is essential for enabling Single Sign-On (SSO) in your cloud application. Refer to the SAP Help documentation

Configuration Steps

StepsAction Items
1Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for HTTPS
1.1Generate Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)
1.2Add Certificates to the SCC Trust Store
1.3Synchronize the cloud trust with Subaccount IDP
1.4Configure SAP S/4HANA for Principal Propagation (HTTPS)
2Configure SAP Web Dispatcher for Principal Propagation
2.1Import Certificates into SAP Web Dispatcher
2.2Maintain Required Parameters in Web Dispatcher
3Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for RFC using SNC
3.1PSE Setup in SAP Cloud Connector for SNC
3.2Configure the S/4HANA System for RFC SNC Propagation
4Create System Mappings in SAP Cloud Connector
4.1Map HTTPS Connections to SAP Web Dispatcher
4.2Map RFC SNC Connections to S/4HANA Backend
5Create Destination in SAP BTP subaccount for HTTPS and RFC SNC scenario

Step 1: Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for HTTPS

Step 1.1: Generate Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector (SCC)

We must configure the following certificates in Cloud Connector:

  • System Certificate
  • CA Certificate
  • User Certificate (Subject Pattern for Principal Propagation)

Note: It is recommended to use signed certificates. Self-signed certificates will also work.

Generating System Certificate

To configure the System Certificate, go to Configuration ‚Üí On Premise ‚Üí System Certificate ‚Üí Create and import a self-signed certificate. Fill the required details in the pop-up window. The Common Name (CN) represents the server‚Äôs name protected by the SSL certificate.

Generating CA Certificate

A CA certificate signs all the certificates that are used when a request is forwarded from the Cloud with the Cloud principals.

To create the CA certificate, scroll down to the corresponding section and click on the ‚ÄúCreate and import a self-signed certificate‚Äù button.

Generating User Certificate

This sample certificate is used to define the rules in the S/4HANA system under the Transaction code (CERTRULE).

Scroll down to the principal propagation section and edit the Subject Pattern Select the Subject Pattern from the list to assert the user IDs. For example, select ${email} to assert the user against the user‚Äôs mail address propagated from the Cloud.

click on the Create Sample Certificate button.

Choose an email that already exists on the backend system. Please remember that this is only a sample certificate and will be used to create a rule-based mapping on the backend AS ABAP system

Step 1.2: Add Certificates to the SCC Trust Store

In trust store add below certificates

  • S4HANA SSL server standard
  • Web dispatcher server certificate

Step 1.3: Synchronize the cloud trust with Subaccount IDP

By default, the Cloud Connector does not trust any entries which issues tokens for principal propagation. For this reason, we must establish the trust between the Cloud Connector and the IDP of your subaccount on BTP.

Navigate to the ‚ÄúCloud to On-Premise‚Äù and select the tab Principal Propagation. Click on Synchronise this populate the trust configuration.

Step 1.4: Configure SAP S/4HANA for Principal Propagation (HTTPS)

Now we will do the required configuration in ABAP system.

Step 1.4.a: Import Certificates into the ABAP SSL Server Standard (Transaction: STRUST)

Below certificates need to be imported.

  • cloud connector system certificate imported in s4hana ssl server standard
  • web dispatcher client certificate imported in s4hana ssl server standard

Step 1.4.b: Define Rule-Based Mapping with User Certificate (Transaction: CERTRULE)

Click on the ‚ÄúImport Certificate‚Äù button to import the User certificate that was downloaded from the Cloud Connector. In the ‚ÄúCertificate Attr.‚Äù choose you attribute mapping from the drop-down menu. In the ‚ÄúLogin As‚Äù select E-Mail and press enter.

Once you save your new rule you should see a similar screen as below where the ‚ÄúMapping Status‚Äù and ‚ÄúUser Status‚Äù are both green.

Step 1.4.c: Maintain Reverse Proxy and other parameters in the Default Profile (Transaction: RZ10)

Copy Subject and issuer values from web dispatcher client certificate and Cloud Connector System Certificate

For following parameter: icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_<x> = SUBJECT="<subject>", ISSUER="<issuer>".

  • Select a free index for <x>.
  • <subject> is the subject of the certificate (example data: CN=SCC, OU=BTP Scenarios, O=Trust Community, C=DE).
  • <issuer> is the issuer of the certificate (example data: CN=MyCompany CA, O=Trust Community, C=DE).

Example: icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_2 = SUBJECT="CN=SCC, OU=BTP Scenarios, O=Trust Community, C=DE", ISSUER="CN=MyCompany CA, O=Trust Community, C=DE".

Parameter name

Value

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_0

Copy subject and issuer values from web dispatcher client certificate

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_1

Copy subject and issuer values from cloud connector system certificate

login/certificate_mapping_rulebased

1

icm/HTTPS/verify_client

1

Step 1.4.d: Set Logon Procedure to ‚ÄúRequired with SSL Certificate‚Äù for Relevant SICF Services

To access ICF services via certificate logon, make sure that all required ICF services allow Logon Through SSL Certificate as logon method.

Step 2: Configure SAP Web Dispatcher for Principal Propagation

If you are using an intermediate SAP Web Dispatcher to connect to your ABAP backend system, you must set up a trust chain between the involved components Cloud Connector, SAP Web Dispatcher, and ABAP backend system.

We need to Configure SAP Web Dispatcher to trust the Cloud Connector's certificate for identity propagation. Parameters and certificates need to be added.

Make sure your SAP Web Dispatcher supports SSL and configuration done for Web Dispatcher to Forward SSL Certificates for X.509 Authentication. Refer SAP Help documentation for pre-requisites.

Step 2.1: Import Certificates into SAP Web Dispatcher

Below Certificates to be added in web dispatcher PSEs.

  • cloud connector CA certificate in web dispatcher server standard pse (SAPSSLS.pse )
  • s4hana ssl server standard certificate in web dispatcher client pse (SAPSSLC.pse)

Step 2.2: Maintain Required Parameters in Web Dispatcher

Create icm trusted reverse proxy parameters same as we did in Step 1.4.c

Parameter name

Value

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_0

Copy subject and issuer values from cloud connector CA certificate

icm/trusted_reverse_proxy_1

Copy subject and issuer values from s4hana ssl server standard certificate

Make sure icm/HTTPS/verify_client parameter is set to 1 (request certificate) or 2 (require certificate). If set to 0, trust cannot be established. The default value is 1, so it is OK if the parameter is not set at all.

Your HTTPS Principal Propagation configuration is now complete for the scenario where a Web Dispatcher is used as an intermediary between the ABAP backend system.

Step 3: Configure Principal Propagation to an ABAP System for RFC using SNC

For enabling Principal Propagation over RFC using Secure Network Communication (SNC), follow the steps below.
If you've already configured HTTPS-based principal propagation on the same S/4HANA system, steps such as certificate generation, trust setup, and user mapping (via STRUST and CERTRULE) may have already been completed. You only need to ensure the SNC-specific configurations.

Make sure SNC setup on the ABAP System is already present. Ensure SAP Cryptographic library is installed as a pre-requisite in cloud connector.

Note: It is important that you use the same SNC implementation on both communication sides. When using the SAP Cryptographic Library, it is recommended that you use an ABAP system SNC identity and a Cloud Connector system identity signed by the same CA for mutual authentication.

Step 3.1: PSE Setup in SAP Cloud Connector for SNC

Step 3.1.a: Login to OS level of SCC then Download and extract the SAP Cryptographic Library. You can refer SAP Help documentation.
Step 3.1.b: Ensure you have set the Environment variables SECUDIR and SNC_LIB

Step 3.1.c: Create SNC PSE at OS level. Navigate to path Crypto and execute below commands

You can Refer SAP Help documentation and below note.

2642538 - How to enable SNC from external programs to ABAP using SAP RFC Connectors

To Create SNC PSE: sapgenpse gen_pse -p SCC.pse "CN=SCC, OU=<name>, O=<name>, C=<name>"

It is recommended that you sign the CSR of PSE with a trusted CA and then import it. Self-signed will also work.

Import Signed Certificate: sapgenpse import_own_cert -p SCC.pse -x <pin> -c SCC.cer -r <RootCA>.cer

Create credentials for the SNC PSE: sapgenpse seclogin -p SCC.pse -O <sccuser>

Note: sccuser is the user under which cloud connector is running.

Adding ABAP SNC certificate in Cloud connector PSE (download from S/4HANA, STRUST --> SNC): sapgenpse maintain_pk -p SCC.pse -a S4HANA.cer

Step 3.1.d: Restart Cloud connector below SNC SECUDIR parameter will appear in Cloud connector UI Configuration tab. (Library path and My name details we need to give).

Once you have created the SNC PSE and imported the required certificates into it, take restart and login to cloud connector UI to define the SNC name

Step 3.2: Generate Certificates in Cloud Connector

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step1.1. You may skip it if the certificates were already generated during the HTTPS setup.)

Step 3.3: Add Certificates to the Trust Store in SCC

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.2. S4hana SSL server standard certificate needs to be added.)

Step 3.4: Synchronize Cloud Trust with Subaccount Identity Provider (IdP)

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.3. You can skip this step if already done.)

Step 3.5: Configure the S/4HANA System for RFC SNC Propagation

Step 3.5.a: Import Certificates into the SSL Server Standard (Transaction: STRUST)

Below certificates needs to be added.

  • cloud connector system certificate imported in S/4HANA SSL server standard
  • cloud connector PSE SNC certificate imported in S/4HANA SNC cryptolib
Step 3.5.b: Define Rule-Based Mapping for the user certificate (Transaction: CERTRULE)

(This step is identical to the HTTPS scenario Step 1.4.b. You can skip this step if user mapping has already been configured and login/certificate_mapping_rulebased parameter set to 1)

Step 3.5.c: Configure SNC Identity in the backend system (Transaction: SNC0)

Login to backend ABAP system and execute transaction SNC0 and add cloud connector‚Äôs SNC identity. Note the SNC name from SAP Cloud connector.

Step 4: Create System Mappings in SAP Cloud Connector

We need to create Mapping Virtual To Internal System in the Cloud To On-Premise tab for your subaccount in Cloud connector.

Step 4.1: Map HTTPS Connections to SAP Web Dispatcher

Since we are using a Web Dispatcher as an intermediary to the ABAP backend system, we will define the Web Dispatcher host in the HTTPS destination configuration instead of the ABAP system directly. The flow will be like this.

BTP (Service) --> cloud connector --> web dispatcher --> S/4HANA

Parameter

Value

Backendtype

Other SAP system

Protocol

HTTPS

Host of the web dispatcher

Internal Port

Port of the web dispatcher

Enter any value but avoid underscores in the name.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Virtual Port

Enter any numerical value.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Principal Type

Select the mapping you just created and add the Resources as per your requirement.

Step 4.2: Map RFC SNC Connections to S/4HANA Backend

Enter any value but avoid underscores in the name.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Enter any numerical value.
Note: Remember your entry as you need it to configure the destination in your SAP BTP subaccount.

Select the mapping you just created and add the Resources as per your requirement.

Naming Policy

Step 5: Create Destination in SAP BTP

Create destinations in BTP subaccount to allow communication between S/4HANA and SAP BTP for HTTPS and RFC SNC protocol.

Step 5.1: For HTTPS scenario, enter the below information:

Parameter

Value

Name

S4Hana _HTTP

Type

HTTP

Proxy Type

On-Premise

Location ID

Copy this from cloud connector subaccount overview section

URL

http://<host:port as defined in Cloud Connector>

Proxy Type

OnPremise

PrincipalPropagation

Additional Properties

sap-client

Client number of your system

Step 5.2: For RFC scenario, enter the below information:

Parameter

Value

Name

S4Hana_RFC

Type

Proxy type

On-Premise

Copy this from cloud connector subaccount settings

create Technical User in S/4HANA and enter user id and

Repository Password

<host as defined in Cloud Connector>

jco.client.client

Client number in SAP S/4HANA

jco.client.sysnr

<instance number as defined in Cloud Connector>

Conclusion

By completing these steps, you have successfully configured Principal Propagation from SAP BTP to your on-premises ABAP system for both HTTPS and RFC (via SNC) communication. You can now integrate any SAP BTP service and use Principal Propagation as the authentication method to ensure secure, user-specific access.

For troubleshooting Cloud Connector principal propagation over HTTPS, Refer SAP Help documentation.

Feel free to share your feedback or questions in the comments.üòä
